ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

My Role
Plaintiff
Status

Forum

Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

A-000313-25 – Street Crossing Appeal

A-000313-25 · Docket A-000313-25

Case Type
Appeal (Appellate Division)
Status
Active
Forum
Appellate Division
Role
Appellant
appellate street-crossing due-process

Case Overview

This is an Appellate Division matter stemming from a municipal street-crossing enforcement encounter in Atlantic County, New Jersey, and the resulting conviction. The appeal concerns the legality and procedural handling of the stop, subsequent enforcement actions, and post-conviction consequences.

Case Overview

This case record maintains a factual, chronological archive for A-000313-25, an Appellate Division matter arising from an encounter in Atlantic County involving an alleged jaywalking violation and subsequent law enforcement actions.

According to the appellant’s account, the incident began when the appellant was stopped as a pedestrian by Officer Boyd of the Township of Hamilton Police Department, who allegedly assumed the appellant had crossed directly from a neighborhood across the street, resulting in claims of bias and profiling. The appellant asserts being harassed for identification, driver’s license, and Social Security number, and after refusing to provide private information—following Officer Boyd’s assurance that no ticket would be issued—invoked constitutional and New Jersey rights. The encounter escalated, resulting in the appellant being tackled, arrested, and charged in Superior Court with hindering an investigation, obstruction of justice, and resisting arrest. The appellant states that a plea was entered to a disorderly persons offense in Superior Court to resolve the matter expediently.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Special Civil Part — Atlantic County

ATL-DC-007956-25 – Toll Enforcement

ATL-DC-007956-25 · Docket ATL-DC-007956-25

Case Type
Civil Collection (Toll Enforcement)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Defendant / Counterclaimant
toll-enforcement discovery accessibility due-process

Case Overview

Active Special Civil Part action arising from alleged unpaid toll assessments. Defendant asserts counterclaims and defenses challenging process integrity, notice, data accuracy, and accessibility, including the need for reasonable accommodations to ensure meaningful participation.

Case Overview

This Special Civil Part matter involves toll-enforcement collection claims brought against the Defendant. Notably, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTA) has raised its claimed damages to over $8,000 for an alleged $365 in unpaid tolls, asserting authority to collect under New Jersey law and citing the appellate case Long v. NJTA. However, this case is not applicable to the Defendant’s situation, as the Defendant is not Long, but Devon, who is enrolled in EA and government assistance programs and is actively engaged in sustained efforts to live a civil, lawful life. The Defendant asserts that actions by certain state actors in New Jersey have made this extremely difficult.

The Defendant has asserted counterclaims and affirmative defenses challenging the integrity of the enforcement process, the accuracy of toll data, and barriers to meaningful access and participation in court proceedings.

The record reflects ongoing disputes concerning service, proof of liability, discovery compliance, and the provision of reasonable accommodations necessary for a fair hearing.

Status Overview

  • 19 Aug 2025: Complaint and summons served alleging unpaid toll assessments.
  • 3 Sep 2025: Answer and First Appearance filed, asserting defenses and raising jurisdictional objections and the need for ADA-related accommodations.
  • 8 Oct 2025: Counterclaim and discovery packet served, alleging damages arising from toll-enforcement practices and vendor data irregularities.
  • 27 Oct 2025: Court issued an order addressing default and discovery issues; subsequent correspondence in November 2025 continued to press for accessible hearings and complete discovery.
  • Ongoing: Matter remains active with unresolved discovery, accessibility, and due-process issues.

The encounter escalated, resulting in the appellant being tackled, arrested, and charged in Superior Court with hindering an investigation, obstruction of justice, and resisting arrest. The appellant states that a plea was entered to a disorderly persons offense in Superior Court to resolve the matter expediently.

Faith Frontier maintains this page to (1) preserve a coherent timeline, (2) centralize filings and orders for public inspection, and (3) reduce ambiguity created by fragmented or duplicated folders. This page is not a substitute for the official court docket; it is an indexed reference layer that points back to primary-source documents.

Scope and Integrity Rules (Faith Frontier Standard)

  • Primary sources control. Where a summary conflicts with an order, notice, filing stamp, or docket entry, the primary source controls and the summary must be corrected.
  • No assumptions. If a fact (date, caption, originating docket, disposition) is not confirmed by a document, it is described as unconfirmed and left neutral.
  • Neutral tone. This archive preserves claims and positions as asserted, while labeling them as assertions unless adjudicated.

Procedural Posture

  • Forum: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Special Civil Part — Atlantic County

ATL-DC-007956-25 – Toll Enforcement

ATL-DC-007956-25 · Docket ATL-DC-007956-25

Case Type
Civil Collection (Toll Enforcement)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Defendant / Counterclaimant
toll-enforcement discovery accessibility due-process

Case Overview

Active Special Civil Part action arising from alleged unpaid toll assessments. Defendant asserts counterclaims and defenses challenging process integrity, notice, data accuracy, and accessibility, including the need for reasonable accommodations to ensure meaningful participation.

Case Overview

This Special Civil Part matter involves toll-enforcement collection claims brought against the Defendant. Notably, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTA) has raised its claimed damages to over $8,000 for an alleged $365 in unpaid tolls, asserting authority to collect under New Jersey law and citing the appellate case Long v. NJTA. However, this case is not applicable to the Defendant’s situation, as the Defendant is not Long, but Devon, who is enrolled in EA and government assistance programs and is actively engaged in sustained efforts to live a civil, lawful life. The Defendant asserts that actions by certain state actors in New Jersey have made this extremely difficult.

The Defendant has asserted counterclaims and affirmative defenses challenging the integrity of the enforcement process, the accuracy of toll data, and barriers to meaningful access and participation in court proceedings.

The record reflects ongoing disputes concerning service, proof of liability, discovery compliance, and the provision of reasonable accommodations necessary for a fair hearing.

Status Overview

  • 19 Aug 2025: Complaint and summons served alleging unpaid toll assessments.
  • 3 Sep 2025: Answer and First Appearance filed, asserting defenses and raising jurisdictional objections and the need for ADA-related accommodations.
  • 8 Oct 2025: Counterclaim and discovery packet served, alleging damages arising from toll-enforcement practices and vendor data irregularities.
  • 27 Oct 2025: Court issued an order addressing default and discovery issues; subsequent correspondence in November 2025 continued to press for accessible hearings and complete discovery.
  • Ongoing: Matter remains active with unresolved discovery, accessibility, and due-process issues.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

ATL-L-002794-25 · Docket ATL-L-002794-25

My Role
Plaintiff
Status

Forum
Trial Court
Judge
Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

Plaintiff asserted claims sounding in contract, fiduciary duty, statutory consumer fraud, fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, and limited conviction-dependent malpractice. By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

toll-enforcement discovery accessibility due-process

Case Overview

Active Special Civil Part action arising from alleged unpaid toll assessments. Defendant asserts counterclaims and defenses challenging process integrity, notice, data accuracy, and accessibility, including the need for reasonable accommodations to ensure meaningful participation.

Case Overview

This Special Civil Part matter involves toll-enforcement collection claims brought against the Defendant. Notably, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTA) has raised its claimed damages to over $8,000 for an alleged $365 in unpaid tolls, asserting authority to collect under New Jersey law and citing the appellate case Long v. NJTA. However, this case is not applicable to the Defendant’s situation, as the Defendant is not Long, but Devon, who is enrolled in EA and government assistance programs and is actively engaged in sustained efforts to live a civil, lawful life. The Defendant asserts that actions by certain state actors in New Jersey have made this extremely difficult.

The Defendant has asserted counterclaims and affirmative defenses challenging the integrity of the enforcement process, the accuracy of toll data, and barriers to meaningful access and participation in court proceedings.

The record reflects ongoing disputes concerning service, proof of liability, discovery compliance, and the provision of reasonable accommodations necessary for a fair hearing.

Status Overview

  • 19 Aug 2025: Complaint and summons served alleging unpaid toll assessments.
  • 3 Sep 2025: Answer and First Appearance filed, asserting defenses and raising jurisdictional objections and the need for ADA-related accommodations.
  • 8 Oct 2025: Counterclaim and discovery packet served, alleging damages arising from toll-enforcement practices and vendor data irregularities.
  • 27 Oct 2025: Court issued an order addressing default and discovery issues; subsequent correspondence in November 2025 continued to press for accessible hearings and complete discovery.
  • Ongoing: Matter remains active with unresolved discovery, accessibility, and due-process issues.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division — Atlantic County (originating matter)

A-000313-25 – Street Crossing Appeal

A-000313-25 · Docket A-000313-25

Case Type
Appeal (Appellate Division)
Status
Active
Forum
Appellate Division
Role
Appellant
appellate street-crossing due-process

Case Overview

This is an Appellate Division matter stemming from a municipal street-crossing enforcement encounter in Atlantic County, New Jersey, and the resulting conviction. The appeal concerns the legality and procedural handling of the stop, subsequent enforcement actions, and post-conviction consequences.

Case Overview

This case record maintains a factual, chronological archive for A-000313-25, an Appellate Division matter arising from an encounter in Atlantic County involving an alleged jaywalking violation and subsequent law enforcement actions.

According to the appellant’s account, the incident began when the appellant was stopped as a pedestrian by Officer Boyd of the Township of Hamilton Police Department, who allegedly assumed the appellant had crossed directly from a neighborhood across the street, resulting in claims of bias and profiling. The appellant asserts being harassed for identification, driver’s license, and Social Security number, and after refusing to provide private information—following Officer Boyd’s assurance that no ticket would be issued—invoked constitutional and New Jersey rights. The encounter escalated, resulting in the appellant being tackled, arrested, and charged in Superior Court with hindering an investigation, obstruction of justice, and resisting arrest. The appellant states that a plea was entered to a disorderly persons offense in Superior Court to resolve the matter expediently.

Faith Frontier maintains this page to (1) preserve a coherent timeline, (2) centralize filings and orders for public inspection, and (3) reduce ambiguity created by fragmented or duplicated folders. This page is not a substitute for the official court docket; it is an indexed reference layer that points back to primary-source documents.

Scope and Integrity Rules (Faith Frontier Standard)

  • Primary sources control. Where a summary conflicts with an order, notice, filing stamp, or docket entry, the primary source controls and the summary must be corrected.
  • No assumptions. If a fact (date, caption, originating docket, disposition) is not confirmed by a document, it is described as unconfirmed and left neutral.
  • Neutral tone. This archive preserves claims and positions as asserted, while labeling them as assertions unless adjudicated.

Procedural Posture

  • Forum: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part — Atlantic County

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

ATL-L-003252-25 · Docket ATL-L-003252-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status
Closed
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil equitable-relief declaratory-relief dismissed-without-prejudice

Case Overview

This Law Division civil action was dismissed without prejudice. The action originally sought emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1, challenging the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process. A new action is pending.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Docket

next.content:
ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court

civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

next.content:
ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

The Court advised Plaintiff that, once Plaintiff's post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The matter originally arose from alleged attorney misconduct and failure to perform agreed legal services after acceptance of a retainer. Plaintiff asserted claims sounding in contract, fiduciary duty, statutory consumer fraud, fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, and limited conviction-dependent malpractice. By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division — Atlantic County (originating matter)

A-000313-25 – Street Crossing Appeal

A-000313-25 · Docket A-000313-25

Case Type
Appeal (Appellate Division)
Status
Active
Forum
Appellate Division
Role
Appellant
appellate street-crossing due-process

Case Overview

This is an Appellate Division matter stemming from a municipal street-crossing enforcement encounter in Atlantic County, New Jersey, and the resulting conviction. The appeal concerns the legality and procedural handling of the stop, subsequent enforcement actions, and post-conviction consequences.

Case Overview

This case record maintains a factual, chronological archive for A-000313-25, an Appellate Division matter arising from an encounter in Atlantic County involving an alleged jaywalking violation and subsequent law enforcement actions.

According to the appellant’s account, the incident began when the appellant was stopped as a pedestrian by Officer Boyd of the Township of Hamilton Police Department, who allegedly assumed the appellant had crossed directly from a neighborhood across the street, resulting in claims of bias and profiling. The appellant asserts being harassed for identification, driver’s license, and Social Security number, and after refusing to provide private information—following Officer Boyd’s assurance that no ticket would be issued—invoked constitutional and New Jersey rights. The encounter escalated, resulting in the appellant being tackled, arrested, and charged in Superior Court with hindering an investigation, obstruction of justice, and resisting arrest. The appellant states that a plea was entered to a disorderly persons offense in Superior Court to resolve the matter expediently.

Faith Frontier maintains this page to (1) preserve a coherent timeline, (2) centralize filings and orders for public inspection, and (3) reduce ambiguity created by fragmented or duplicated folders. This page is not a substitute for the official court docket; it is an indexed reference layer that points back to primary-source documents.

Scope and Integrity Rules (Faith Frontier Standard)

  • Primary sources control. Where a summary conflicts with an order, notice, filing stamp, or docket entry, the primary source controls and the summary must be corrected.
  • No assumptions. If a fact (date, caption, originating docket, disposition) is not confirmed by a document, it is described as unconfirmed and left neutral.
  • Neutral tone. This archive preserves claims and positions as asserted, while labeling them as assertions unless adjudicated.

Procedural Posture

Superior Court of New Jersey, Special Civil Part — Atlantic County

ATL-DC-007956-25 – Toll Enforcement

ATL-DC-007956-25 · Docket ATL-DC-007956-25

Case Type
Civil Collection (Toll Enforcement)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Defendant / Counterclaimant
toll-enforcement discovery accessibility due-process

Case Overview

Active Special Civil Part action arising from alleged unpaid toll assessments. Defendant asserts counterclaims and defenses challenging process integrity, notice, data accuracy, and accessibility, including the need for reasonable accommodations to ensure meaningful participation.

Case Overview

This Special Civil Part matter involves toll-enforcement collection claims brought against the Defendant. Notably, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTA) has raised its claimed damages to over $8,000 for an alleged $365 in unpaid tolls, asserting authority to collect under New Jersey law and citing the appellate case Long v. NJTA. However, this case is not applicable to the Defendant’s situation, as the Defendant is not Long, but Devon, who is enrolled in EA and government assistance programs and is actively engaged in sustained efforts to live a civil, lawful life. The Defendant asserts that actions by certain state actors in New Jersey have made this extremely difficult.

The Defendant has asserted counterclaims and affirmative defenses challenging the integrity of the enforcement process, the accuracy of toll data, and barriers to meaningful access and participation in court proceedings.

The record reflects ongoing disputes concerning service, proof of liability, discovery compliance, and the provision of reasonable accommodations necessary for a fair hearing.

Status Overview

  • 19 Aug 2025: Complaint and summons served alleging unpaid toll assessments.
  • 3 Sep 2025: Answer and First Appearance filed, asserting defenses and raising jurisdictional objections and the need for ADA-related accommodations.
  • 8 Oct 2025: Counterclaim and discovery packet served, alleging damages arising from toll-enforcement practices and vendor data irregularities.
  • 27 Oct 2025: Court issued an order addressing default and discovery issues; subsequent correspondence in November 2025 continued to press for accessible hearings and complete discovery.
  • Ongoing: Matter remains active with unresolved discovery, accessibility, and due-process issues.

content:
ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).
title: ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

case_type: Civil Action (Attorney Misconduct / Contract and Tort Claims)
overview: This Law Division civil action was closed gracefully by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C. on 2026-01-09. The Court advised Plaintiff that, once Plaintiff's post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The matter originally arose from alleged attorney misconduct and failure to perform agreed legal services after acceptance of a retainer. Plaintiff asserted claims sounding in contract, fiduciary duty, statutory consumer fraud, fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, and limited conviction-dependent malpractice. By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Declaratory and Equitable Relief (Vehicle Ownership and Indemnity)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

Case Overview

This Law Division civil action was dismissed without prejudice. ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

next.content:
ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Declaratory and Equitable Relief (Vehicle Ownership and Indemnity)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role

civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

ATL-DC-007956-25 – Toll Enforcement

ATL-DC-007956-25 · Docket ATL-DC-007956-25

Case Type
Civil Collection (Toll Enforcement)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Defendant / Counterclaimant
toll-enforcement discovery accessibility due-process

Case Overview

Active Special Civil Part action arising from alleged unpaid toll assessments. Defendant asserts counterclaims and defenses challenging process integrity, notice, data accuracy, and accessibility, including the need for reasonable accommodations to ensure meaningful participation.

Case Overview

This Special Civil Part matter involves toll-enforcement collection claims brought against the Defendant. Notably, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority (NJTA) has raised its claimed damages to over $8,000 for an alleged $365 in unpaid tolls, asserting authority to collect under New Jersey law and citing the appellate case Long v. NJTA. However, this case is not applicable to the Defendant’s situation, as the Defendant is not Long, but Devon, who is enrolled in EA and government assistance programs and is actively engaged in sustained efforts to live a civil, lawful life. The Defendant asserts that actions by certain state actors in New Jersey have made this extremely difficult.

The Defendant has asserted counterclaims and affirmative defenses challenging the integrity of the enforcement process, the accuracy of toll data, and barriers to meaningful access and participation in court proceedings.

The record reflects ongoing disputes concerning service, proof of liability, discovery compliance, and the provision of reasonable accommodations necessary for a fair hearing.

Status Overview

  • 19 Aug 2025: Complaint and summons served alleging unpaid toll assessments.
  • 3 Sep 2025: Answer and First Appearance filed, asserting defenses and raising jurisdictional objections and the need for ADA-related accommodations.
  • 8 Oct 2025: Counterclaim and discovery packet served, alleging damages arising from toll-enforcement practices and vendor data irregularities.
  • 27 Oct 2025: Court issued an order addressing default and discovery issues; subsequent correspondence in November 2025 continued to press for accessible hearings and complete discovery.
  • Ongoing: Matter remains active with unresolved discovery, accessibility, and due-process issues.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

previous.content:
ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Declaratory and Equitable Relief (Vehicle Ownership and Indemnity)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. The action challenges the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process, and seeks immediate return of property and related equitable relief.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Case Overview

This Law Division civil action was dismissed without prejudice. The action originally sought emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1, challenging the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process. A new action is pending.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

previous.content:
ATL-L-002794-25 – Barber v. Tumelty

Case Overview

This Law Division action was closed on January 9, 2026, by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C., who advised Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber that, once Plaintiff’s post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The case originally arose from Defendants’ alleged failure to perform agreed legal services after accepting a retainer in connection with Plaintiff’s pretrial detention and related criminal proceedings.

Plaintiff had alleged that Defendants abandoned representation, failed to communicate, failed to pursue available pretrial remedies, and retained fees without providing contracted services. The action asserted multiple independent causes of action sounding in contract, tort, and statute, rather than a single malpractice theory alone.

Claims Asserted

Plaintiff’s operative pleadings asserted claims including, but not limited to:

  • Breach of contract;
  • Breach of fiduciary duty;
  • Common-law fraud and fraudulent misrepresentation;
  • Violation of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act;
  • Negligence and professional misconduct;
  • Unjust enrichment;
  • Limited conviction-dependent legal malpractice (pled in the alternative and expressly preserved).

previous.overview: This Law Division civil action was closed gracefully by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C. on 2026-01-09. The Court advised Plaintiff that, once Plaintiff's post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The matter originally arose from alleged attorney misconduct and failure to perform agreed legal services after acceptance of a retainer. Plaintiff asserted claims sounding in contract, fiduciary duty, statutory consumer fraud, fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, and limited conviction-dependent malpractice. By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division — Atlantic County

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Declaratory and Equitable Relief (Vehicle Ownership and Indemnity)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

ATL-L-003252-25 · Docket ATL-L-003252-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status
Closed
Forum
Trial Court
Role
