civil equitable-relief declaratory-relief dismissed-without-prejudice

Case Overview

This Law Division civil action was dismissed without prejudice. The action originally sought emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1, challenging the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process. A new action is pending.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

MER-L-002371-25 · Docket MER-L-002371-25

Status
Active

Trial Court

civil equitable-relief declaratory-relief

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. The action challenges the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process, and seeks immediate return of property and related equitable relief.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

previous.overview: This Law Division civil action was closed gracefully by Hon. Sarah B. Johnson, J.S.C. on 2026-01-09. The Court advised Plaintiff that, once Plaintiff's post-conviction relief (PCR) is adjudicated, Plaintiff may refile the complaint against John W. Tumelty, Esq. and The Law Offices of John W. Tumelty. The matter originally arose from alleged attorney misconduct and failure to perform agreed legal services after acceptance of a retainer. Plaintiff asserted claims sounding in contract, fiduciary duty, statutory consumer fraud, fraud, negligence, unjust enrichment, and limited conviction-dependent malpractice. By court order, the matter was reassigned to Track 3 based on complexity and the presence of multiple independent claims.

ATL-L-002869-25 – Barber v. CarMax

ATL-L-002869-25 · Docket ATL-L-002869-25

Case Type
Civil Action – Declaratory and Equitable Relief (Vehicle Ownership and Indemnity)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Plaintiff
civil declaratory-relief equitable-relief vehicle-title indemnity

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking declaratory and equitable relief concerning disputed vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from vehicle sale and registration records. Plaintiff challenges inaccurate or conflicting records used for enforcement purposes and seeks judicial clarification of rights and responsibilities. Related pleadings and track assignment activity remain pending.

Case Overview

This Law Division action is brought by Plaintiff Devon Tyler Barber against CarMax and related entities. The action seeks declaratory and equitable relief to resolve disputes concerning vehicle ownership, title status, and indemnity obligations arising from the sale, registration, and subsequent use of vehicle records for enforcement and administrative purposes.

Plaintiff alleges that inaccurate, inconsistent, or improperly maintained vehicle records resulted in enforcement actions and legal exposure inconsistent with the true ownership and contractual allocation of responsibility. The action seeks a judicial declaration clarifying ownership, liability, and indemnity rights.

Core Issues Presented

  • Whether Plaintiff retained ownership or legal responsibility for the vehicle at issue following the transaction with CarMax;
  • Whether title and registration records accurately reflected the parties’ rights and obligations;
  • Whether Defendants bear indemnity or corrective obligations arising from errors or omissions in vehicle-transfer documentation;
  • Whether declaratory and equitable relief is necessary to prevent continued or future enforcement based on erroneous records.

Procedural Posture

  • 14 Oct 2025: Verified Complaint filed, accompanied by an indigency affidavit, initiating the Law Division action.
  • 17 Oct 2025: Track Assignment Notice issued recognizing the declaratory nature of the action; Plaintiff requested reassignment consistent with comparable Track 3 matters.
  • 29 Oct 2025: Amended Complaint filed clarifying requests for declaratory relief, related damages, and constitutional claims tied to enforcement consequences.
  • Ongoing: Proofs of service, responses, and discussions concerning corrective action and indemnity remain in progress; no final dispositive orders have issued.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

This Law Division civil action was dismissed without prejudice. The action originally sought emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1, challenging the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process. A new action is pending.

ATL-L-003252-25 – Equitable Relief

Case Overview

Docket No.: ATL-L-003252-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Atlantic County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

Case Overview

Active Law Division civil action seeking emergent equitable and declaratory relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. The action challenges the warrantless seizure and continued retention of Plaintiff’s vehicle without statutory authority, judicial process, or due process, and seeks immediate return of property and related equitable relief.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: Township of Hamilton; Officer Edward Ruiz; Officer Bryan Merritt; Officer Cristian Martin; Officer Kyle McKnight; Officer Rachel Hare; Sergeant Dennis Bakker; Sergeant Gary Clune; Officer Nijon Isom
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Status: Closed (dismissed without prejudice) – New action pending

Pattern and Supplemental Discovery

This case arises from a pattern of conduct by the Township of Hamilton Police Department. Notably, this is the same department (but a different chief and all different officers) as involved in Plaintiff’s 2024 incident with Officer Boyd. The present matter involves Officer Ruiz and others, but demonstrates similar issues regarding police conduct, lack of transparency, and disregard for due process. Plaintiff is seeking supplemental discovery to establish this pattern and practice—not to relitigate prior incidents, but to show the existence of a systemic issue relevant to the claims and relief sought here.

In this incident, Officer Ruiz forcibly removed Plaintiff from his vehicle without explanation, despite Plaintiff’s civil demeanor and requests for clarification. Body-worn camera (BWC) footage reveals a prolonged stop (approximately 20 minutes before returning to Plaintiff’s window), during which Officer Ruiz prevented others from communicating with Plaintiff and manipulated the sequence of events. These actions, along with the department’s refusal to release the vehicle absent payment of fees, support Plaintiff’s request for equitable and declaratory relief and further discovery into departmental practices.

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On November 29, 2025, Hamilton Township police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges (including disorderly conduct, obstruction, and resisting arrest), none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • The Atlantic County Prosecutor’s Office confirmed in writing that it possesses no 911 call, CAD entry, dispatch record, or call-for-service documentation supporting either the stop or the impoundment.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Criminal Part — Atlantic County

Barber PCR (2022) – State v. Barber (Hardemon matters)

Barber PCR (2022) · Docket ATL-22-002292

Case Type
Post-Conviction Relief (R. 3:22)
Status
Active
Forum
Trial Court
Role
Petitioner
post-conviction-relief pcr criminal due-process ineffective-assistance

Case Overview

Consolidated post-conviction relief proceedings challenging a 2022 conviction and related proceedings. The petition asserts violations of due process, ineffective assistance of counsel, lack of notice, and record integrity failures arising from the handling of the underlying prosecution and sentencing. Verified petitions and supporting certifications were filed in October 2025, with requests for record supplementation and assignment of counsel pending.

Case Overview

This matter consists of consolidated Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) proceedings brought by Devon Tyler Barber under Rule 3:22, challenging a 2022 conviction adjudicated in Atlantic County. The origins of this case trace back to a wage dispute between Barber and his former employers. The PCR petitions relate to matters commonly referenced as the Hardemon cases and are consolidated here to ensure a unified record and consistent judicial review.

Petitioner alleges that the conviction and subsequent proceedings were tainted by due-process violations, failures of notice, deficiencies in the record, and ineffective assistance of counsel, resulting in an unreliable adjudication. It is further asserted that Barber’s former employers engaged in improper and retaliatory conduct during the underlying proceedings, contributing to the alleged injustices and procedural irregularities.

Grounds Asserted

The PCR petitions assert, among other grounds:

  • Denial of due process, including lack of proper notice and opportunity to be heard;
  • Ineffective assistance of counsel, including failure to challenge jurisdictional and procedural defects;
  • Record integrity failures, including missing, inaccurate, or untransmitted materials;
  • Fundamental fairness violations impacting the validity of the conviction and sentence.

These claims are asserted pursuant to Rule 3:22-2(a) and related provisions.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County

Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.

MER-L-002371-25 – Emergency Injunction (Mercer)

Case Overview

Docket No.: MER-L-002371-25
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Law Division, Civil Part – Mercer County
Plaintiff: Devon Tyler Barber (pro se)
Defendants: City of Trenton; Officer John Doe 1; Officer John Doe 2
Case Type: Civil Action – Verified Complaint & Order to Show Cause (Emergency Injunctive Relief)
Primary Relief Sought: Immediate return of unlawfully impounded vehicle; declaratory and equitable relief

Nature of the Action

This is an emergent civil action seeking immediate injunctive and equitable relief under R. 4:52-1 and R. 4:67-1. Plaintiff challenges the seizure and continued retention of his 2019 Volkswagen Passat (NJ Plate F35VLP), which was taken and held without statutory authority, court order, forfeiture process, or constitutionally adequate due process.

Core Facts

  • On December 7, 2025, Trenton police officers seized Plaintiff’s vehicle following a traffic stop and custodial arrest.
  • The arrest resulted in municipal-level charges, none of which authorize vehicle impoundment under Title 39 or any forfeiture statute.
  • The vehicle was operable, legally parked, not contraband, not evidence, and posed no public-safety hazard at the time of seizure.
  • No forfeiture complaint, warrant, inventory, or judicial order has ever been issued authorizing continued retention of the vehicle.
  • Defendants have refused to release the vehicle unless towing and storage fees are paid, despite the impoundment being unlawful ab initio.

These facts are set forth in sworn certifications and a verified complaint filed with the Court.
